titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Gabriel Ersler Papers and Photographs ALBA.198
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Gail Malmgreen

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2012-04-20T13:28-0400

did.unittitle: Gabriel Ersler Papers and Photographs
did.langmaterial: Materials are in English, French, Polish, and Hebrew.
did.abstract: Dr. Gabriel Ersler (1913-2005) was born in Woclawek, Poland and studied medicine in Berlin and in Bern, Switzerland. He went to Spain in 1937 and became a staff doctor at the Centre de Instruccion de Madrigueras, Albacete. He then became chief of the medical unit of the 13th International Brigade. As an exile in France after the Spanish Civil War he joined the anti-fascist Resistance. In 1956 he moved from the Soviet Union back to his native Poland, where he became disillusioned by the resurgence there of anti-semitism and, in 1968, emigrated to France. By the 1970s he was living in Israel and practicing there as an eye specialist; during this period he also embarked on a major research project to create a biographical directory of foreign (and especially Jewish) volunteers in the medical units of the International Brigades. He published articles on the medical service in several languages, sometimes as G. E. Sichon or Gabriel Ersler Sichon, incorporating his mother's maiden name in the Spanish style. The collection contains a copy of extracts from Dr. Ersler's Notebook, kept in Spain, in 1937-1939; some souvenir items of stationery from Civil War-era Spain; copies of lists of International Brigades volunteers; copies of articles by Ersler and others; and a file of correspondence between Ersler and ALBA archivist Victor Berch. Also included is a series of photographs taken by Ersler in Spain in 1937-1938.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized in 2 series: I, Subject Files, 1937-1987; II, Photographs and Photo Inventory, 1937-1938 and Undated.
Series I is arranged alphabetically; Series II is arranged by photograph number.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Material
relatedmaterial.p: ALBA collection at the Tamiment Library.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:

New York, NY 10012

Fax: (212) 995-4225

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The collection contains a copy of extracts from Dr. Ersler's Notebook, kept in Spain, in 1937-1939; some souvenir items of stationery from Civil War-era Spain; copies of lists of International Brigades volunteers; copies of articles by Ersler and others; and a file of correspondence between Ersler and ALBA archivist Victor Berch. Also included is a series of photographs taken by Ersler in Spain in 1937-1938.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: Most of these materials were donated to the ALBA archive by Dr. Gabriel Ersler in 1973; some may have been sent in later years. Items were sent by mail (along with donations of related books), to archivist Victor Berch at Brandeis University. The Ersler Papers and Photographs came to New York University in January 2001 as part of the original acquisition of ALBA collections, formerly housed at Brandeis.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Dr. Gabriel Ersler (1913-2005) was born in Woclawek, Poland and studied medicine in Berlin until 1933 and in Bern, Switzerland until 1936. He went to Spain in 1937 and became a staff doctor at the Centre de Instruccion de Madrigueras, Albacete. He then became chief of the medical unit of the 13th International Brigade. As an exile in France after the Spanish Civil War he joined the anti-fascist Resistance. In 1956 he moved from the Soviet Union back to his native Poland, where he became disillusioned by the resurgence there of anti-semitism and, in 1968, emigrated to France. By the 1970s he was living in Israel and practicing there as an eye specialist. He traveled widely in Europe with his first wife, Conchita; after her death he married again, to Janine Szurek, and lived in his later years in France.

He embarked on a major research project to create a biographical directory of foreign (and especially Jewish) volunteers in the medical units of the International Brigades. In the course of this work he corresponded with, and eventually visited, Fredericka Martin, who was carrying out related research from her home in Cuernavaca, Mexico. He also corresponded with Victor Berch, archivist of the Lincoln Brigades collections at Brandeis University. Ersler published articles on the medical service in several languages, sometimes as G. E. Sichon or Gabriel Ersler Sichon, incorporating his mother's maiden name in the Spanish style.

did.unittitle: Series I: Subject Files, 1937-1987.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Contains a copy of extracts from Dr. Ersler's Notebook, kept in Spain, 1937-1939; some souvenir items of stationery from Civil War-era Spain; copies of lists of International Brigades volunteers; copies of articles by Ersler and others; and a file of correspondence between Ersler and ALBA archivist Victor Berch.

did.unittitle: Articles on the Medical Service in Spain, by G. Ersler and Others, from Ochotnik Wolnosci(in Polish; photostats and photocopies)
Correspondence between GE and Victor Berch
Extracts from a Notebook Kept by G. Ersler in Spain (typescript copy; in Polish)
Gohke, Dr. Nikolis, "Moja lekarska iskustva u spanskom ratu," from Vojnosanitetski Pregled (Yugoslavia, photocopy)
List of Czechoslovakian Jewish Volunteers, Compiled by Union des Anciens Resistants Juife de Belgique
Lists of Jewish Volunteers of Various Nationalities (photocopies, from several sources, in Polish, French, and Hebrew)
Sichon, G. E. [G. Ersler], "Eliasz Hilsenrad -- 'Maciek Techniczek'" (typescript in Polish; with excerpts from two other essays or comments)
Sichon, G. E. [G. Ersler], "Polonais, d'origine juive, volontaires de la guerre civil en Espagne, 1936-1939" (typescript, with related notes)
Souvenir Stationery (Hospital/Clinic) and a Blank Postcard, from Spain
Series II: Photographs and Photo Inventories, 1937-1938 and Undated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Contains black and white prints of photographs taken in Spain by Ersler, labeled with his original photograph numbers, and an inventory compiled by Victor Berch from Ersler's caption information. Ersler explains the history of these photographs in his letter to Berch of February 9, 1973 (in Folder 1A, above).
